awd_titl_txt: AF: Small: Approximation algorithms for quantum mechanical problems
awd_abstract_narration:
A fundamental problem in computer science is the constraint satisfaction problem MAX-SAT, which asks: Given a set of Boolean constraints on n bits, what is the maximum number of constraints which can be simultaneously satisfied by an assignment to all the bits? Despite its many applications, MAX-SAT is unfortunately believed to be impossible to solve efficiently. Fortunately, such problems can often be solved approximately via so-called approximation algorithms.
In the quantum setting, a physically motivated generalization of MAX-SAT exists, known as LH, which concerns the computation of important properties of quantum systems at very low temperatures. Unfortunately, like MAX-SAT, LH is also believed intractable. This project hence asks the question: Can we compute approximate solutions to k-LH via the framework of approximation algorithms? 
The resolution of this question will yield deep insight into our ability to approximately compute properties of quantum systems in nature. The results obtained will be disseminated through a variety of avenues, including conferences, high school workshops, and engineering public lecture series aimed at exposing the general public to the frontiers of research.
 At a high level, this project aims to design polynomial-time approximation algorithms for a variety of classes of the local Hamiltonian problem (LH), from physically motivated special cases to more general settings. The techniques used are inspired primarily by ideas from the fields of approximation algorithms and quantum information theory. Among other results, a key aim of the project is to obtain insight into how well classically efficiently representable quantum states can approximate solutions to genuinely quantum problems involving ground spaces of local Hamiltonians.

por.por_cntn:
With the current rise in prominence of the quantum computational paradigm, now is an apt time to recall the original motivation for quantum computers - to simulate and compute properties of physical quantum systems in the lab. Indeed, simulation of physical systems is generally considered intractable on existing classical computer technology, although it is key to significant potential discoveries such as the design of nanomaterials and medication. For this reason, the majority of supercomputers around the world are currently focused on simulating (in a rather inefficient manner) such systems.

This project makes progress on the question of computing properties of physical systems (in particular, low temperature many-body systems), in both positive and negative directions. On the positive end, it gives efficient classical algorithms for approximately computing the so-called "ground state energy" of such systems (this is the energy of the quantum system when it is cooled to near absolute zero). The papers (Hallgren et al., APPROX/RANDOM 2020) and (Gharibian & Parekh, APPROX/RANDOM 2019) make progress here, with the former addressing a larger class of quantum systems, and the latter being specialized to a specific notoriously difficult physical model (known as the Heisenberg anti-ferromagnet) but producing higher accuracy as a tradeoff.

On the negative end, the papers (Gharibian et al., arXiv:1805.11139) and (Gharibian & Yirka, Quantum 2019) use tools from computational complexity theory to show that, assuming standard conjectures, a related and remarkably natural problem is intractable: That of cooling a given quantum many-body system to near absolute zero, and then making a "simple" single-qubit measurement on it. The particular focus of these works is to show that not only is this problem hard in general, but it is hard even for the "simplest" and "most physically motivated" quantum systems, such as for quantum particles arranged in a 1D chain (which is the simplest possible configuration), or for the 2D Heisenberg model (which is among the most physically motivated and well-studied in physics.)

Taken together, these results reveal two sides of the same coin: One the one hand, certain problems are (up to standard conjectures) provably intractable to solve in general, such as simulating measurements on low-temperature systems. On the other hand, problems such as estimating ground state energies can efficiently achieved on a classical computer, if the margin of required precision is "reasonable".

Finally, all three of papers (Gharibian et al. arXiv:1805.11139), (Gharibian et al., STACS 2020), and (Gharibian & Yirka, Quantum 2019) also make progress on understanding "quantum proof verification" procedures. These are procedures in which we imagine an honest party (the "verifier") wishes to be convinced of a particular fact (say the verifier wishes to verify a "quantum password" for a bank account). To help achieve this, we allow the verifier to have a quantum computer, and the "user" or "prover" in this scenario sends the verifier a quantum state to act as a "proof", which the verifier can process using his/her quantum computer. In this setting, for example the first of the three papers gives one of the first quantum generalizations of a very thoroughly studied classical proof system known as the "Polynomial Time Hierarchy". Here, we find that a "Quantum Polynomial Time Hierarchy" can have seemingly drastically varying power, depending on whether it employs quantum or classical proofs/messages.
